user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock:
```c
static void
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  const uint32_t K[] = { 0x5A827999, 0x6ED9EBA1, 0x8F1BBCDC, 0xCA62C1D6 };
  int i;
  uint32_t temp;
  uint32_t W[80];
  uint32_t A, B, C, D, E;

  for (i = 0; i < 16; i++)
  {
    W[i] = ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4]) << 24;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 1]) << 16;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 2]) << 8;
    W[i] |= context->message_block[i * 4 + 3];
  }
  for (i = 16; i < 80; i++)
  {
    W[i]
      = SHA1CircularShift (1, W[i - 3] ^ W[i - 8] ^ W[i - 14] ^ W[i - 16]);
  }
  A = context->intermediate_hash[0];
  B = context->intermediate_hash[1];
  C = context->intermediate_hash[2];
  D = context->intermediate_hash[3];
  E = context->intermediate_hash[4];
  for (i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | ((~B) & D)) + E + W[i]
           + K[0];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 20; i < 40; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[1];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 40; i < 60; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | (B & D) | (C & D)) + E
           + W[i] + K[2];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 60; i < 80; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[3];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  context->intermediate_hash[0] += A;
  context->intermediate_hash[1] += B;
  context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
  context->intermediate_hash[3] += D;
  context->intermediate_hash[4] += E;
  context->message_block_index = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the statement 'context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;' does not use any of the <string.h> functions listed by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. The rule concerns functions like memcpy/memset/strcpy/etc. A concrete violation example would be calling something like memcpy(context->intermediate_hash, src, 6*sizeof(uint32_t)) when intermediate_hash only has 5 elements, which would access beyond the object bounds.
